chapter.htmlHeader: When should I suspect fungal nail infection?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
Be aware that fungal nail infection commonly co-exists with other nail disorders that may present similarly. Suspect a diagnosis of fungal infection clinically if:

  • The nail looks abnormal and is discoloured. A single nail, several, or rarely all nails may be affected. The first and fifth toenails are most commonly involved. Fingernail infection is usually unilateral. Different presentations of onychomycosis include:
    • Superficial white — small flaky white patches and pits on the top of the nail plate; the nail becomes roughened and friable as infection spreads to the deeper layers of nail. Most common in children.
    • Distal — begins distally and spreads to the nail plate and nail bed; the end of the nail is lifted up, and the free edge erodes. As infection spreads proximally, may cause linear channels or 'spikes'. May be associated with Candida infection.
    • Lateral — white or yellow opaque streaks along one side of the nail.
    • Proximal — white or yellow spots appear in the lunula, the proximal growing end of the nail. Debris may accumulate under the proximal portion of the nail, causing onycholysis and a white discoloration that spreads distally. Most cases involve the toenails.
    • Subungual hyperkeratosis — scaling under the distal nail; the nail is discoloured, opaque, and thickened.
    • Endonyx — infection of the nail plate with white discolouration, in the absence of onycholysis and subungual hyperkeratosis.
    • Total dystrophic — marked thickening and hyperkeratosis; the nail plate is almost completely destroyed. Primary total dystrophy is rare, is usually caused by Candida infection, and typically affects immunocompromised people.
    • Associated with paronychia — usually, proximal nail fold infection with painful redness and swelling of the periungual skin, and possible pus collection. Typically pressure on and movement of the nail is painful. Candida infection is likely. See the CKS topic on Paronychia - acute for more information.
  • Note: some nails have features from a combination of different classes. Images of these presentations of fungal nail infection are available at www.dermnetnz.org/fungal/onychomycosis.html.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on when to suspect fungal nail infection are based on expert opinion in the British Association of Dermatologists' Guidelines for the management of onychomycosis 2014 [Ameen, 2014], a network meta-analysis of onychomycosis treatments [Gupta, 2015], and expert opinion in review articles on fungal nail infection [Westerberg, 2013; Eisman, 2014].

  • Classification of different presentations of fungal nail infection is useful, as this may help to guide management options and predict prognosis [Westerberg, 2013].
  • The classification framework is based on the morphologic pattern of involvement, and mode of invasion of the nail [Westerberg, 2013].
  • The first and fifth toenails are most commonly affected, as they are more likely to be damaged by footwear [Ameen, 2014].
